cells.data:
Welcome to Quiver! This tutorial will help you get started.

Quiver is a note-taking app built for programmers. Its unique cell-based design lets you easily mix text and code within one note, edit code with an awesome code editor, and find any note instantly via the full-text search.

Jump Right In

If you want to start using Quiver right away, just remember one thing: a note in Quiver is comprised of cells. Cells are snippets of text or code that you can freely mix. You can even set different language modes for different code cells inside one note.

Click inside a new note and start typing. Press “shift+return” (⇧⏎) to create a new cell and use “backspace” to merge cells. That’s all you need to know to start using Quiver. 

But if you want to learn more, keep reading.

Cells

Currently three types of cells are supported:
  1. A “Text Cell" lets you edit rich-text in-place.
  2. A “Code Cell” packs an awesome code editor, with syntax highlighting support for most languages.
  3. A “Markdown Cell” lets you write in Markdown, with inline formatting and custom CSS options.
For example, this is a text cell with some formatting applied.
You can change text styles by using the toolbar on top of this note, or use standard keyboard shortcuts, such as ⌘B for bold.
More complex text and paragraph styles are also supported. You can find those options under the “Format” menu.
This is an example of a text cell with complex styles applied.
A code cell packs the powerful ACE code editor, which supports syntax highlighting for most languages, over 20 themes, automatic indent and outdent, etc.

# And this is a code cell set to the CoffeeScript mode

hello = ->
    console.log 'Hello World!'

## Markdown Cell

This is a markdown cell. You can use common markdown syntax here.

Basic formatting of *italic* and **bold** is supported.

So is `inline code`.

And lists.

### Ordered list

1. Item 1
2. A second item
3. Number 3
4. Ⅳ

### Unordered list

* An item
* Another item
* Yet another item
* And there's more...

### Quote

> Here is a quote.

Custom CSS options can be set in the *Preferences* panel.
You can change the language mode in the toolbar above the note. You can set the default cell type in the Preferences panel.

Sometimes you might want to convert one cell type to another. You can use the popup button in the toolbar to do that, or keyboard shortcuts (⌥⌘1 to convert to text cell, ⌥⌘2 to convert to code cell, ⌥⌘3 to convert to markdown cell). You can find these options under the “Cell” menu, too.

Cell Operations

Cell operations in Quiver are very powerful, while intuitive to learn.

The most important one is to create a new cell, which you have already learned. Press “shift+return” (⇧⏎) to create a new cell below the current cell. The new cell is created in the text cell mode, but you can quickly convert it to a code cell if you want (tip: use keyboard shortcut ⌥⌘2).

Another important cell operation is to merge two cells. Simply place the cursor at the beginning of the second cell, then press the “backspace” key. Note that you can’t merge cells of different types.

You can also cut, copy or paste a cell, split a cell, move a cell up or down. All these cell operations and their corresponding keyboard shortcuts can be found under the “Cell” menu.

To copy a code snippet to the clipboard, click inside the code cell, and press ⇧⌘C.
